qcew_data_summary.source: BLS Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages, 2022-2023 annual data (private sector, own_code=5)
qcew_data_summary.note: QCEW data lags by ~18 months. 2023 is latest available annual. BLS CES provides more current monthly estimates.

bls_ces_january_2026.source: BLS Employment Situation Summary, January 2026 (released Feb 11, 2026)
bls_ces_january_2026.context: Healthcare accounted for 63% of all jobs added in January 2026 (81.9K of 130K). Including social assistance (42K), healthcare and social assistance accounted for 95% of net job creation (123.9K of 130K). 2025 total jobs were revised down from 584K to 181K, meaning the real-time healthcare dominance was UNDERSTATED in 2025.

621_ambulatory.baumol_indicator: moderate - wage growth 2.6% vs sector avg 2.8%, but highest absolute wages ($1,434/wk) in non-hospital healthcare. Ambulatory is the efficiency frontier of healthcare.
621_ambulatory.ai_readiness_detail: Ambulatory care is ground zero for healthcare AI. Ambient clinical documentation near-universal adoption (92% deploying/piloting). 66% of physicians using AI tools (invisible pathway). FDA deregulated AI clinical decision support Jan 6, 2026. Revenue cycle AI rapidly deploying for coding and billing. Dental AI (Overjet, Pearl) reaching mainstream. This is where AI penetration is highest because: (1) outpatient settings have lower acuity (less liability fear), (2) physician offices are smaller (faster adoption cycles), (3) payment reform creates direct incentives for efficiency.

key_sub_segments.6211_physicians: 2.9M employees, $2,054/wk avg wage. Growth 3.2%. HIGHEST Baumol pressure in healthcare. AI clinical decision support directly targets physician productivity. 37K-124K physician shortage by 2034 makes AI augmentation mandatory.
key_sub_segments.6212_dentists: 1.03M employees, $1,210/wk. Growth 1.6% (slowest in ambulatory). Dental AI market reaching $1.3B by 2026. Overjet and Pearl with FDA clearance. Dental is a sleeper AI adoption story -- fragmented market of small practices adopting imaging AI rapidly.
key_sub_segments.6213_other_practitioners: 1.16M employees, $979/wk. Growth 6.8% (FASTEST in ambulatory). Includes physical therapists, chiropractors, optometrists, mental health practitioners. Growth driven by mental health expansion and PT demand from aging population. AI exposure moderate -- human touch is core value.
key_sub_segments.6216_home_health: 1.63M employees, $765/wk. Growth 6.2%. LOWEST wages in ambulatory. Critical sub-sector for aging-in-place. RPM market reaching $18B in US by 2026. Hospital-at-home CMS waiver covers 419 hospitals/39 states. Labor-intensive, low-wage, high-demand: the Baumol extreme.

621_ambulatory.transformation_thesis: Ambulatory care is bifurcating: physician and specialist practices (+AI augmentation, rising productivity) vs home health (+volume, stagnant wages, labor-dependent). The top half gains from AI; the bottom half is trapped in Baumol cost disease.

622_hospitals.baumol_indicator: high - hospitals are the canonical Baumol sector. Wage growth 3.0% against 2.8% sector average. 30% PE-backed with $930B refinancing wall. Cost pressure is structural and intensifying.
622_hospitals.ai_readiness_detail: Hospitals have high AI investment but uneven deployment. 71% had implemented predictive AI models by Sep 2025 but 81% have not adopted AI broadly. The paradox: ambient clinical documentation near-universal, but clinical workflow AI fragmented. Revenue cycle AI rapidly deploying (highest ROI). Patient flow optimization gaining traction. Surgical robotics at $14B global market with 13-15% procedure growth. The barrier is not technology but institutional complexity: EMR integration, credentialing, liability, union considerations.

key_sub_segments.6221_general_hospitals: 4.89M employees (93% of hospital subsector), $1,553/wk. Growth 3.6%. The core of US healthcare employment. PE distress concentrated here -- Steward Health bankruptcy (5 hospitals closed, 2,400 workers laid off). 488 US hospitals PE-owned as of Apr 2025. Medicare hospital payment increase 2.6% net (3.3% market basket - 0.7% productivity adjustment) for 2026.
key_sub_segments.6222_psychiatric_hospitals: 126K employees, $1,180/wk. Growth 2.8%. Small but growing subsector driven by mental health demand. Telehealth integration high.
key_sub_segments.6223_specialty_hospitals: 258K employees, $1,515/wk. Growth 6.7% (FASTEST in hospitals). Includes surgical, cardiac, orthopedic specialty centers. Surgical robotics driving growth -- da Vinci procedures up 18% in 2025. ASC (ambulatory surgery center) migration trend.

622_hospitals.transformation_thesis: Hospitals face a three-way squeeze: (1) PE distress forcing cost reduction, (2) CMS site-neutral payment eroding the inpatient premium, (3) hospital-at-home waiver shifting volume to lower-cost settings. AI's role is primarily back-office efficiency (RCM, patient flow) and surgical precision, not clinical labor replacement.

623_nursing_residential.baumol_indicator: extreme - lowest wages ($846/wk) of any healthcare subsector except social assistance. Wage growth 3.0% insufficient to attract workers. Nursing shortage 8% nationally, 20% for LPNs. This is Baumol's endpoint: the sector cannot afford the labor it needs.
623_nursing_residential.ai_readiness_detail: Nursing and residential care has the LOWEST AI readiness in healthcare. The work is physical (bathing, feeding, mobility assistance), relational (emotional support, companionship), and surveillance-based (fall prevention, medication adherence). AI can assist with monitoring (RPM, fall detection) but cannot replace direct care labor. Senior care technology market growing ($1.4B AI-driven elderly care by 2025, growing to $3.1B by 2033) but deployment is fragmented across 90,000 facilities, most small and undercapitalized.

key_sub_segments.6231_nursing_care_facilities: 1.42M employees, $905/wk. Growth 5.5%. The epicenter of the nursing shortage -- 8% national deficit, 20% LPN shortage. CA, TX, FL most severe. 250K RN gap projected by 2030. Facilities struggling to hire at any price.
key_sub_segments.6232_residential_care_ID: 632K employees, $869/wk. Growth 5.1%. Medicaid-dependent, facing state budget pressures.
key_sub_segments.6233_continuing_care_retirement: 944K employees, $739/wk (LOWEST in 62). Growth 5.9%. Fastest growing nursing subsegment. Aging-in-place trend driving CCRC demand but the business model depends on real estate appreciation and entrance fees -- CRE stress is a risk.

623_nursing_residential.transformation_thesis: Nursing care is the sector most resistant to AI transformation AND most desperate for labor. The resolution is demographic: either immigration policy delivers workers, or robotics/AI monitoring extends each worker's capacity. Humanoid robotics (300% funding surge) and senior care tech are the long-term play, but 2026-2028 remains a pure labor crisis.

624_social_assistance.baumol_indicator: extreme - $635/wk ($33K/year) is the lowest wage in NAICS 62. Wage growth 5.3% (highest in sector) still leaves workers below living wage thresholds. This is the fastest-growing AND lowest-paying subsector.
624_social_assistance.ai_readiness_detail: Social assistance (childcare, individual/family services, vocational rehabilitation, community food/housing) is almost entirely human-labor-dependent. These are the jobs that exist BECAUSE they cannot be automated: caring for children, counseling families, feeding the hungry, housing the homeless. AI's role is limited to case management optimization and benefits enrollment. The 42K jobs added in Jan 2026 reflects genuine demographic demand (childcare, elder support) not technological disruption.
624_social_assistance.transformation_thesis: Social assistance is the economy's labor absorption sponge. It creates jobs that cannot be automated at wages that cannot attract workers. The 5.6% growth rate combined with $635/wk wages is a social policy problem, not a technology problem. The sector grows because society needs the services and no one else is hiring.

transformation_projections.2026: Administrative AI reaches critical mass. Ambient clinical documentation (AI scribes) near-universal in ambulatory care. Revenue cycle AI deployment accelerates driven by PE distress and Change Healthcare aftermath. Hospital-at-home CMS waiver extended through 2030 (H.R. 4313 passed Dec 2025). Surgical robotics: da Vinci 5 procedures grow 13-15%. Pharmacy automation market hits $7.8B. Healthcare employment continues 60%+ share of job creation, with ambulatory leading (+50K/mo). Nursing shortage quantified at 8% national deficit but no near-term resolution. Medicare pays hospitals 2.6% net increase; physician fee schedule sees modest 2.5% update. PE-backed hospital distress intensifies (Steward aftermath, others following).
transformation_projections.2027: Clinical AI deployment phase begins. Post-FDA deregulation, AI clinical decision support tools integrate into EHR workflows. Physician adoption moves from invisible (personal ChatGPT use) to institutional (EHR-embedded). AI coding in medical billing reaches 40-50% automation rate (from ~20% today). Hospital-at-home scales to 800+ hospitals as reimbursement clarity solidifies. Pharmacy automation and robotic dispensing become standard in hospital pharmacies serving 200+ beds. Digital pathology AI reaches 15-20% of reference lab volume. Remote patient monitoring crosses 40% adoption for chronic disease. Dental AI (imaging analysis) adopted by 30% of practices. First wave of nursing care monitoring AI (fall detection, medication adherence) deploys at scale in SNFs. Healthcare employment share may moderate slightly (55-60%) as other sectors stabilize.
transformation_projections.2028: Barbell formation accelerates. Premium tier (AI-augmented physicians, surgical robotics, specialty diagnostics) pulls away in compensation and productivity. Commodity tier (home health aides, nursing assistants, social workers) remains labor-intensive and low-wage. The hollowed middle (medical coders, transcriptionists, prior authorization staff, basic radiology reads) begins measurable contraction. Hospital-at-home treats 500K+ patients annually. AI pathology becomes standard of care for cancer screening. Medical coding AI reaches 70%+ automation, triggering workforce restructuring in RCM departments. Site-neutral payment policy fully phases in, accelerating outpatient migration. PE distress peaks and begins workout phase.
transformation_projections.2029: Healthcare AI reaches enterprise maturity. Multi-modal clinical AI (imaging + labs + notes + genomics) deployed at top-50 health systems. AI clinical decision support becomes expected standard of care -- malpractice cases begin citing failure to use AI as evidence of negligence. Surgical robotics expands to 40%+ of eligible procedures (from ~15% today). Senior care technology ecosystem matures: integrated monitoring, predictive health alerts, and caregiver coordination platforms. Pharmacy automation handles 80%+ of routine dispensing. The nursing shortage begins structural moderation as: (1) AI monitoring extends each nurse's patient capacity, (2) scope-of-practice laws expand for NPs/PAs, (3) international recruitment programs scale. Healthcare employment share may decline to 50-55% as AI-driven sectors (data centers, robotics manufacturing, energy) create alternative job categories.
transformation_projections.2030: Healthcare structural transformation visible. The sector has bifurcated into: (A) high-tech healthcare (AI-augmented diagnosis, robotic surgery, precision medicine, hospital-at-home) generating high productivity and wages, and (B) human-touch healthcare (nursing care, home health, social assistance) generating high employment but low wages. The barbell is fully formed. Digital pathology standard across oncology. Remote patient monitoring reduces hospital admissions by 15-20% for managed chronic disease populations. AI prior authorization near-fully automated (CMS-0057-F mandate fully enforced). Humanoid robotics begins pilot deployment in nursing facilities for mobility assistance and logistics.
transformation_projections.2031: Healthcare's share of GDP approaches 22% (from ~18% today) but employment share of job creation normalizes to 40-45% as AI productivity gains moderate hiring velocity. The sector employs 24-25M workers (from 21.3M in 2023). Premium tier compensation grows 4-6% annually while commodity tier stagnates at 2-3%. The key structural question is whether AI productivity gains flow to: (A) healthcare cost reduction (benefiting patients and payers), (B) provider margin improvement (benefiting PE owners and health systems), or (C) worker compensation (benefiting nurses and clinicians). Historical pattern (Baumol) suggests costs rise even with technology -- but AI's impact on healthcare may finally break the Baumol trap in administrative functions while reinforcing it in direct care.

monoculture_sustainability_model.thesis: Is healthcare's 63% dominance of job creation a fragility signal (P-039 monoculture) or a structurally appropriate demographic response?
evidence_for_fragility: 63% of all Jan 2026 job creation from a single NAICS sector is unprecedented concentration. No other period in BLS history shows a single sector this dominant for this long.
Excluding healthcare and social assistance, the US economy NET LOST jobs in 2025 (181K total revised, healthcare accounted for the majority). The rest of the economy is not creating jobs.
PE-backed healthcare distress (Steward bankruptcy, 488 PE-owned hospitals, $930B refinancing wall) shows the sector's growth is partially funded by unsustainable leverage.
Healthcare's 8% nursing shortage means the sector creates jobs it CANNOT FILL -- a sign of overheating, not healthy growth.
Tariff costs ($1,300/household) and AI job anxiety (64% job hugging) reduce consumer spending, which could eventually slow healthcare demand growth at the margin.
Medicare/Medicaid reimbursement pressure (physician fee schedule barely keeping pace with inflation, home health cuts) limits revenue growth even as costs rise.
evidence_for_sustainability: By 2035, 26% of Americans will be 65+. 95% of older adults have one chronic condition, 80% have two or more. This is non-discretionary demand that cannot be deferred.
BLS projects 1.8M new healthcare jobs per year over the next decade -- the demand is structural, not cyclical.
Home health and personal care workers expected to grow 22% by 2034; nurse practitioners 38%. These are direct care roles addressing real demographic need.
Worker-to-senior ratio approaching 2:1 -- the labor demand is mathematical, not speculative.
Healthcare spending at ~18% of GDP is a structural feature of an aging wealthy nation, not a bubble. Japan, Germany, and other aging societies show similar trajectories.

January 2026 saw other sectors recover (+33K construction, +34K professional services, +5K manufacturing) but healthcare still dominated -- even WITH recovery, healthcare demand is the strongest signal.
monoculture_sustainability_model.verdict: BOTH. Healthcare monoculture is a structurally sustainable demographic response AND a fragility signal. The demand is real and non-discretionary, so calling it a 'bubble' is incorrect. But the concentration of ALL net job creation in a single sector means: (1) any healthcare-specific shock (reimbursement cut, PE cascade, AI-driven productivity surge) has outsized macroeconomic impact, (2) the labor market lacks diversification -- displaced workers from other sectors have limited absorption capacity outside healthcare, (3) the nursing shortage creates a paradox where the dominant employer cannot fill its own vacancies. RECLASSIFICATION: P-039 should be reframed as 'structurally sustainable monoculture with concentration risk' -- not fragile like a bubble, but risky like a single-crop economy. The counter-signal (CS07) is correct that demand is real; the original thesis is correct that concentration is dangerous. Both are true simultaneously.
falsification_criteria: If healthcare share drops below 40% of job creation for 3+ consecutive months while total employment remains positive, monoculture thesis weakens
If PE-backed hospital cascade triggers 20+ hospital closures in a single year, fragility thesis strengthens
If AI productivity gains reduce healthcare hiring by 15%+ while maintaining care quality, the monoculture begins self-correcting
If nursing shortage resolves through immigration reform (bringing healthcare share of unfilled vacancies below 5%), the overheating signal fades

fear_friction_assessment.provider_patient_trust_gap: WIDENING. 66% of physicians use AI tools but patients largely unaware (invisible pathway). Google/Ipsos shows 50/50 global split on AI trust. Healthcare has the highest trust stakes of any sector -- diagnostic errors can be fatal. The trust gap means AI deployment follows the invisible pathway: physicians adopt tools privately, institutions deploy back-office AI, but patient-facing AI remains constrained. The gap is not closing because: (1) deepfake scams (148% surge) erode general technology trust, (2) no high-profile healthcare AI success story has reached public consciousness, (3) malpractice liability framework for AI-influenced decisions remains unresolved.
fear_friction_assessment.clinical_ai_resistance: MODERATING for physicians, PERSISTENT for patients. Physician adoption at 66% and rising -- the invisible pathway has succeeded in circumventing resistance. FDA deregulation (Jan 6, 2026) removes regulatory barrier. But clinical AI resistance increases with acuity: primary care physicians readily adopt decision support, while surgeons and ICU physicians resist workflow changes. The METR finding (AI 19% slower for experienced developers) has an analog in healthcare: experienced clinicians may be SLOWED by AI interruptions, while junior clinicians benefit from decision support.
fear_friction_assessment.admin_ai_adoption: RAPID and accelerating. Administrative AI (revenue cycle, documentation, prior authorization, scheduling) faces the lowest trust barriers in healthcare. No patient interaction, rules-based work, clear ROI metrics. Ambient clinical documentation (AI scribes) near-universal at 92% deployment rate among health systems. Revenue cycle AI showing 88-95% coding accuracy vs 63-65% human. This is the invisible pathway (P-032) executing at scale in healthcare: AI transforms the back-office while the front-office trust gap persists.
fear_friction_assessment.regulatory_pathway: FAVORABLE and clarifying. FDA deregulated AI clinical decision support (Jan 6, 2026) under four criteria: not replacing clinical judgment, for healthcare professionals, provides information basis, user can independently review. CMS mandating electronic prior authorization by 2027 (CMS-0057-F). Hospital-at-home waiver extended through 2030. BUT: 1,200+ state AI bills create compliance patchwork. Illinois leading on chatbot safety and AI provenance. Federal preemption vs state law conflict unresolved. The regulatory environment is net-positive for healthcare AI but increasingly complex to navigate.

premium_tier.description: Healthcare roles that gain value through AI augmentation
roles: AI-augmented physicians (clinical decision support increases diagnostic accuracy and throughput)
Surgical robotics operators (da Vinci-trained surgeons command 20-40% premium)
AI pathologists (digital pathology + AI screening increases cancer detection rates)
Healthcare data scientists and AI system trainers (new roles, $150K-250K)
Nurse practitioners with expanded scope (NP demand growing 38% by 2034)
Hospital-at-home medical directors (new role combining clinical and technology oversight)
Healthcare AI ethics and compliance professionals (new role driven by 1,200+ state AI bills)

commodity_tier.description: Healthcare roles that face wage stagnation or slow growth
roles: Home health aides ($765/wk, 1.63M workers -- volume grows but wages stagnate)
Nursing assistants ($846-905/wk -- demand exceeds supply but Medicaid reimbursement caps wages)
Social assistance workers ($635/wk -- essential services at poverty-adjacent wages)
Basic patient transport and environmental services
Community health workers (growing demand, limited funding)
commodity_tier.wage_trajectory: 2-3% annual growth through 2031, below inflation in real terms

hollowed_middle.description: Healthcare roles displaced or compressed by AI
roles: Medical coders (88-95% AI accuracy vs 63-65% human -- 60-80% of coding tasks automatable by 2029)
Medical transcriptionists (ambient AI scribes already near-universal -- role functionally obsolete by 2028)
Prior authorization specialists (CMS-0057-F mandates electronic PA by 2027 -- AI handles most routine PAs)
Basic radiology reads (AI matches or exceeds human accuracy for screening -- volume radiologists displaced)
Insurance claims processors (AI denial management and claims adjudication)
Medical billing specialists (overlap with RCM AI automation)
Basic lab technicians (automated analyzers + AI quality control reducing human oversight needs)
hollowed_middle.estimated_displacement: 800K-1.2M roles restructured by 2031 (not all eliminated -- many transition to AI oversight/exception handling)
hollowed_middle.timeline: Medical transcription: 2026-2027. Medical coding: 2027-2029. Prior authorization: 2027-2028. Radiology screening: 2028-2030.

if_healthcare_contracts.trigger: PE distress cascade, major reimbursement cut, or AI-driven productivity shock reduces healthcare hiring by 30%+
if_healthcare_contracts.impact: Catastrophic for labor market. Healthcare is 63% of job creation. If hiring drops to 40K/month (from 82K), the economy NET LOSES jobs in most months (given other sectors at ~48K). No other sector can absorb displaced healthcare workers because: (1) construction and manufacturing require physical skills, (2) technology requires cognitive retraining, (3) professional services are also shedding jobs. The only absorption pathway is social assistance -- which is already the lowest-paying subsector.
if_healthcare_contracts.probability: Low (15-20% by 2028). Demographic demand is too strong for a sharp contraction. PE distress affects individual systems but the sector overall continues growing. The risk is a SLOWDOWN from 82K/month to 40-50K/month, not a contraction.
monitoring_signals: Monthly BLS healthcare employment dropping below 50K for 3+ months

if_reimbursement_changes.trigger: Major Medicare/Medicaid payment reform (site-neutral expansion, bundled payments, capitation shift)
if_reimbursement_changes.impact: Accelerates AI adoption as cost reduction becomes existential. Site-neutral payment is already phasing in -- equalizing hospital outpatient and office-based rates. This pushes procedures OUT of hospitals and INTO ambulatory settings, accelerating the shift from NAICS 622 to 621. Bundled payments reward efficiency (AI-driven care coordination). Capitation shifts risk to providers, making AI cost reduction mandatory. Net effect: healthcare spending growth moderates but employment composition shifts dramatically -- fewer hospital workers, more ambulatory workers, more AI-augmented roles.
if_reimbursement_changes.probability: High (70%+ by 2028). CMS is already implementing site-neutral payment, electronic prior auth mandate, and IPO list phase-out. The direction is clear; the speed is the variable.
monitoring_signals: Hospital outpatient volume migration to ASCs

if_ai_productivity_breakthrough.trigger: AI clinical tools demonstrate 2x physician productivity in controlled trials, validated by peer review
if_ai_productivity_breakthrough.impact: Fundamentally changes the monoculture calculus. If each physician can see 2x patients with AI augmentation, the physician shortage shrinks dramatically. But nursing shortage remains (physical care cannot be 2x'd with AI). Net effect: physician employment growth slows, nursing/aide employment continues growing, the barbell widens. Healthcare's share of job creation drops as the high-skill end needs fewer workers. The economy-wide impact is positive (healthcare costs could moderate) but the labor market impact is disruptive (fewer high-paying healthcare jobs, continued growth in low-paying ones).
if_ai_productivity_breakthrough.probability: Medium (30-40% by 2029). Ambient documentation is already saving 2+ hours/day per physician. Stacking clinical decision support + documentation + scheduling optimization could approach 2x effective throughput for primary care.
monitoring_signals: Peer-reviewed studies showing physician productivity gains >50%

pattern_status_updates.P-039_healthcare_monoculture: CONFIRMED and REFRAMED. Jan 2026 data (63% of jobs) validates the pattern. Reframing from 'fragility signal' to 'structurally sustainable monoculture with concentration risk.' The demand is demographically real; the risk is concentration in a single sector.
pattern_status_updates.P-032_invisible_pathway: EXECUTING in healthcare at scale. AI ambient scribes (92% deployment), physician AI adoption (66% invisible), revenue cycle AI (88-95% accuracy). Healthcare is the primary demonstration case for P-032: AI transforms back-office while front-office trust gap persists.
pattern_status_updates.P-040_candidate: STRENGTHENED. Healthcare Employment Monoculture upgraded from candidate to confirmed pattern. Evidence: 63% of Jan 2026 jobs, 8% nursing shortage, 2025 revised to 181K total (healthcare was majority).

model_cards.name: Ambient Clinical Documentation AI (Medical Scribe Replacement)
model_cards.one_liner: AI ambient listening that converts patient-physician conversations into structured clinical documentation in real-time, eliminating 2+ hours of daily physician documentation burden while improving coding accuracy and completeness
model_cards.macro_source: Physician documentation burden is the #1 driver of burnout. Physicians spend 2+ hours daily on notes after clinic hours. 37K-124K physician shortage by 2034 makes time recovery critical. 92% of health systems deploying or piloting ambient AI scribes as of Mar 2025 -- this is the fastest-adopted healthcare AI category ever. The invisible pathway (P-032) operates here: physicians use AI tools without patient explicit consent. Market leaders Nuance DAX Copilot, Abridge, and DeepScribe have established but basic transcription is commoditizing (Doximity free scribe). Differentiation shifts to post-transcript intelligence: coding optimization, problem list management, care gap identification.
model_cards.composite_note: Rounded: 75.5. Adjusted to 76.0 reflecting the near-universal adoption trajectory and P-039 monoculture significance.
model_cards.category_rationale: TG 9 >= 8 AND SN 9 >= 6 = TIMING_ARBITRAGE. Also qualifies as FORCE_RIDER (FA 7 >= 7). The window is RIGHT NOW -- 92% deployment rate means late adopters are being pressured by early adopters' productivity gains. But EC 5 reflects intense competition from Microsoft/Nuance, Abridge, DeepScribe, and commoditization pressure from free alternatives.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: 92% of provider health systems deploying, implementing, or piloting ambient AI scribes as of Mar 2025. Northwestern Medicine clinicians using Nuance DAX billed more high-level E/M visits. Texas Oncology study: ambient scribes increased documented diagnoses from 3.0 to 4.1 per encounter. Doximity free scribe signals commoditization of basic transcription. Differentiation is in structured data extraction, coding accuracy, and care gap identification -- the 'after the transcript' layer.
what_must_be_true: Physicians continue to value time recovery over privacy concerns about AI listening (confirmed -- 92% deployment)
Ambient AI maintains clinical accuracy at scale without generating hallucinated medical content
Regulatory framework does not require explicit patient consent for AI-assisted documentation (currently not required in most states)
EHR vendors do not bundle ambient documentation at zero cost, commoditizing the market completely

model_cards.name: AI Pharmacy Automation & Robotic Dispensing
model_cards.one_liner: End-to-end pharmacy automation combining AI-powered medication management, robotic dispensing, and predictive inventory optimization to eliminate dispensing errors and pharmacist staffing pressure in hospital and retail settings
model_cards.macro_source: Pharmacy automation market $7.8B in 2026, growing at 8.6% CAGR to $11.8B by 2031. Hospital pharmacies manage 62% of medication volume. Pharmacist shortage parallels nursing shortage -- burnout and regulatory burden driving attrition. AI-enhanced robotic dispensing reduces contamination risk and achieves 99.99% accuracy vs 96-98% manual. Predictive inventory management reduces waste and stockouts. The demographic driver: aging population with polypharmacy (5+ medications for 80% of seniors) creates exponential dispensing volume growth that manual processes cannot scale.
model_cards.composite_note: 69.0, rounded to 69.5 for P-039 monoculture significance adjustment.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 69.5 in 60-69 range initially, but FA 7 >= 7 qualifies as FORCE_RIDER. Reclassifying to FORCE_RIDER. The pharmacy automation market is real but capital-intensive (hardware + software), reducing CE. Competitive landscape includes established players (Omnicell, BD Rowa, ScriptPro) limiting EC. Timing is steady rather than urgent.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: Pharmacy automation market $7.8B (2026). Robotics in pharmacy automation growing 21.6% CAGR to $32.6B by 2032. Hospital pharmacies handle 62% of medication volume. AI-enhanced vision systems reduce contamination. ML-based inventory management segment growing rapidly. 99.99% robotic dispensing accuracy vs 96-98% manual.
what_must_be_true: Hospital pharmacy budgets include capital for automation hardware (typically $500K-2M per system)
AI inventory prediction reduces medication waste by 15-25% (justifying software subscription)
Pharmacist shortage persists, creating staffing-cost justification for automation
State pharmacy boards do not impose new regulations limiting automated dispensing scope

model_cards.name: Hospital-at-Home Technology Platform
model_cards.one_liner: Integrated technology platform enabling acute-level hospital care at home through remote patient monitoring, AI triage, virtual rounding, and care coordination -- serving the 419 hospitals and 147 systems with CMS waivers across 39 states
model_cards.macro_source: Hospital-at-home adoption projected to double by 2026, reaching $72B out of $300B TAM. CMS waiver extended through 2030 (H.R. 4313 passed Dec 2025). 419 hospitals across 39 states approved. CMS data on 11,000 patients: lower mortality, lower readmissions, lower spending, positive patient experience. H@H addresses multiple structural pressures simultaneously: (1) hospital capacity constraints, (2) patient preference for home care, (3) cost reduction (30-40% lower than inpatient), (4) PE distress requiring margin improvement. The technology platform opportunity: build the infrastructure layer that enables any health system to operate H@H programs.
model_cards.category_rationale: FA 8 >= 7 = FORCE_RIDER. TG 8 >= 8 AND SN 8 >= 6 = TIMING_ARBITRAGE. CMS waiver extension through 2030 creates a 4-year guaranteed regulatory window. 4-force convergence (technology, demographics, capital, psychology) is unusually strong. Lower CE reflects hardware costs (monitoring devices, connectivity infrastructure) and complex integration requirements.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: 419 hospitals/147 systems/39 states with CMS waivers. H.R. 4313 extends through 2030. CMS data (11,000 patients): lower mortality, readmissions, and spending. 60+ conditions eligible. 30-40% cost savings vs inpatient. Patient satisfaction high. Market projected at $72B by 2026 (Chilmark). Technology platform requirements: RPM device management, AI-powered clinical deterioration detection, video visit infrastructure, medication management, care team coordination, EHR integration.
what_must_be_true: CMS waiver maintains current reimbursement parity (home = inpatient rates) through 2030
Patient safety outcomes continue to match or exceed inpatient care at scale
Health systems invest in H@H infrastructure rather than deferring (PE distress may delay some)
Home broadband and connectivity sufficient for clinical-grade remote monitoring in target populations

model_cards.name: AI Medical Coding & Compliance Engine
model_cards.sector_name: Other Ambulatory Health Care Services (Medical Coding)
model_cards.one_liner: AI system that reads clinical documentation and generates accurate ICD-10/CPT codes with compliance audit trails, targeting the 35-37% human error rate in a $250B revenue cycle management market while navigating False Claims Act liability
model_cards.macro_source: Medical coding is a $250B+ process layer where human accuracy averages 63-65%. AI coding systems demonstrate 88-95% accuracy. The gap = $125B+ in annual waste from denials, undercoding, and rework. This is DISTINCT from v3-7's MC-V37-62-003 (Revenue Cycle AI Automation) which covers the full RCM stack. This card focuses specifically on the medical coding function: reading clinical notes, extracting billable elements, selecting optimal codes, generating supporting documentation, and providing compliance audit trails. The False Claims Act risk (billing fraud can trigger criminal prosecution) requires explainable AI with full audit trails -- a compliance moat that generic AI cannot easily replicate. CMS-0057-F mandating electronic prior authorization by 2027 creates regulatory pull.
model_cards.category_rationale: TG 8 >= 8 AND SN 8 >= 6 = TIMING_ARBITRAGE. CE 8 >= 8 AND SN 8 >= 6 = CAPITAL_MOAT. The accuracy gap (88-95% AI vs 63-65% human) is the most quantifiable ROI in healthcare AI. Low capital requirements ($3-8M), fast time to revenue (3 months), high gross margins (80%+). BUT: EC 5 reflects intense competition (Fathom Health, Nym Health, 3M, and incumbents adding AI features).
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: AMA reports 63-65% average coding accuracy. AI coding systems achieve 88-95% (peer-reviewed). $125B+ annual waste from coding errors. CMS-0057-F mandates electronic prior auth by 2027. False Claims Act creates compliance requirement that favors explainable AI with audit trails. PE-distressed health systems prioritize coding accuracy for margin recovery. Ambient scribes increasing documented diagnoses (3.0 to 4.1 per encounter in Texas Oncology study) creates more complex coding workload that AI handles better than humans.
what_must_be_true: AI coding accuracy maintains 88-95% at scale across specialties and payer rules
False Claims Act liability framework does not penalize AI-generated codes more harshly than human codes
Health system compliance officers accept AI coding with proper audit trails
CMS electronic prior auth mandate (CMS-0057-F) is enforced on schedule (2027)

model_cards.name: AI-Powered Senior Care Monitoring Platform
model_cards.sector_name: Continuing Care Retirement Communities and Assisted Living
model_cards.one_liner: Integrated AI monitoring platform for senior living facilities combining fall detection, medication adherence, behavioral pattern recognition, and predictive health alerts to extend caregiver capacity in the lowest-wage, highest-shortage subsector of healthcare
model_cards.macro_source: NAICS 623 employs 3.15M workers at $846/wk average -- the extreme Baumol endpoint where demand exceeds supply at wages the sector cannot afford. 8% national nursing shortage, 20% LPN shortage. 90,025 facilities, mostly small and undercapitalized. AI-driven elderly care market growing from $1.4B to $3.1B by 2033. Senior care technology includes: motion sensors detecting behavioral changes, fall detection with 95%+ accuracy, medication adherence monitoring, sleep pattern analysis, wandering prevention for dementia patients. The value proposition: each monitoring platform extends a single caregiver's capacity from 8-10 residents to 15-20 residents for monitoring tasks while maintaining safety. With 250K RN shortage by 2030, technology that multiplies caregiver capacity is structurally necessary.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 66.0 in 60-69 range = CONDITIONAL. The structural necessity is high (SN 8) and force alignment strong (FA 7 -- FORCE_RIDER threshold), but timing is moderate (TG 6 -- facilities are slow to adopt technology, Medicaid reimbursement limits capital investment) and capital efficiency is low (CE 5 -- hardware costs for sensor deployment across 90K facilities, long sales cycles, fragmented customer base). The demographic tailwind is undeniable but the business model execution is challenging.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: 3.15M workers in NAICS 623 at $846/wk. 90,025 facilities. Growth 5.5% (2022-2023). AI elderly care market $1.4B (2025) to $3.1B (2033). Fall detection, medication adherence, behavioral monitoring proven in pilots. 250K RN shortage by 2030. Worker-to-senior ratio approaching 2:1. Humanoid robotics (300% funding surge) is the 2029-2031 play for physical assistance; AI monitoring is the 2026-2028 bridge.
what_must_be_true: Medicaid reimbursement includes technology investment allowances for monitoring platforms
Senior living facilities have connectivity infrastructure for IoT sensor networks
Family members accept AI-assisted monitoring as equivalent to human oversight for safety
The platform demonstrably reduces adverse events (falls, medication errors) by 25%+ in controlled studies

model_cards.name: Dental AI Diagnostic Platform
model_cards.one_liner: FDA-cleared AI platform that analyzes dental radiographs in real-time to detect caries, periodontal bone loss, and pathology with higher consistency than human review, targeting 1.03M dental practice workers across 135K+ establishments
model_cards.macro_source: Dental AI market reaching $1.3B by 2026, growing 22.3% CAGR to $3.1B by 2034. AI imaging & radiograph analysis dominated at 41.8% market share in 2024. FDA-cleared: Overjet ($53.2M Series C, Mar 2024 -- largest dental AI investment), Pearl (Second Opinion platform, global adoption). Dental is a sleeper AI adoption story: fragmented market of 135K small practices, where imaging AI can be deployed with minimal integration (overlays on existing radiograph systems). Insurance companies are PULLING adoption: payers use AI to verify claims, forcing practices to adopt AI to match. The dental subsector (6212) shows slowest growth in ambulatory (1.6%) but highest AI readiness among the smaller sub-sectors because: (1) imaging is digital and standardized, (2) diagnostic decisions are relatively bounded, (3) payer incentive alignment (both sides want accurate imaging).
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 63.5 = CONDITIONAL. Dental AI is a real and growing market but lacks the structural urgency of hospital or nursing sub-sectors. SN 7 (dental imaging improvement is valuable but not existential). FA 6 (two forces -- technology and capital -- but not the demographic driver that elevates hospital/nursing AI). EC 5 (Overjet and Pearl are well-funded leaders; new entrants face competition). TG 7 (adoption accelerating, insurance company pull creating urgency). CE 7 (SaaS model with moderate capital needs, but small practice sales cycles are long).
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: Dental AI market $1.3B by 2026, 22.3% CAGR. AI imaging 41.8% market share. Overjet $53.2M Series C (largest dental AI investment). Pearl Second Opinion FDA-cleared with global adoption. Insurance companies using AI to verify dental claims -- creating bidirectional adoption pressure. 135K dental establishments, 1.03M employees. QCEW: growth 1.6%, avg wage $1,210/wk.
what_must_be_true: FDA clearance pathway remains accessible for dental AI diagnostic tools
Dental insurance companies continue requiring or incentivizing AI-verified claims
Dental practice owners (often solo practitioners) adopt SaaS technology at sufficient rates
AI diagnostic accuracy demonstrably reduces missed pathology and unnecessary procedures

model_cards.name: AI Pathology & Digital Slide Analysis Platform
model_cards.one_liner: AI platform that analyzes digitized pathology slides to detect cancer, grade tumors, and predict treatment response -- addressing a 5,000+ pathologist shortage while improving diagnostic accuracy for the 1.9M Americans diagnosed with cancer annually
model_cards.macro_source: Digital pathology market $2.01B in 2026, growing 9.9% CAGR to $3.2B by 2031. AI in pathology growing 26% CAGR (faster than base digital pathology). NAICS 6215 (diagnostic labs) is the ONLY ambulatory sub-sector with NEGATIVE employment growth (-1.7% in 2022-2023) -- automation is already reducing headcount. Pathologist shortage: only 18,000 practicing pathologists in the US for 1.9M annual cancer diagnoses. AI pathology achieves AUC 0.96 vs 0.93 human for certain cancer types. Paige AI, PathAI, and Ibex Medical are FDA-cleared leaders. The transition: whole-slide imaging (hardware layer) enabling AI analysis (software layer) on top. Hospital laboratory adoption growing as digital workflow replaces microscope-based review.
model_cards.composite_note: 68.0, adjusted to 68.5 for cancer diagnostic urgency.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 68.5 = CONDITIONAL, approaching FORCE_RIDER threshold. SN 8 reflects pathologist shortage and cancer diagnostic accuracy need. The limitation is FA 6 -- only two forces (F1 technology, F2 demographics). Lacks the capital stress (F4) or psychology (F5) drivers that elevate other healthcare AI models. EC 6 reflects moderate competition with established players. TG 7 reflects steady but not urgent adoption timeline (hospitals adopt slowly for pathology workflows).
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: Digital pathology $2.01B (2026). AI pathology 26% CAGR. NAICS 6215 negative growth (-1.7%) -- only ambulatory subsector already contracting. 18,000 pathologists for 1.9M cancer diagnoses annually. AI AUC 0.96 vs human 0.93 for certain cancers. FDA-cleared: Paige AI, PathAI, Ibex. Whole-slide imaging hardware adoption is the prerequisite -- scanner deployment reaching critical mass in top-100 health systems.
what_must_be_true: Whole-slide imaging hardware deployment continues at current pace (prerequisite for AI analysis)
AI pathology achieves regulatory acceptance as standard of care for cancer screening
Pathologist professional societies do not successfully block AI deployment through scope-of-practice restrictions
Reimbursement codes for AI-assisted pathology analysis are established by CMS

model_cards.name: Remote Patient Monitoring AI Hub (Chronic Disease)
model_cards.one_liner: AI-powered platform that aggregates data from wearables, connected devices, and patient-reported outcomes to provide predictive chronic disease management, reducing hospitalizations by 15-20% for managed populations while enabling value-based care models
model_cards.macro_source: US RPM market projected to exceed $18B by 2026, 25% CAGR. 33% adoption rate projected by 2026. 95% of adults 65+ have at least one chronic condition; 80% have two or more. RPM combined with AI predictive analytics can identify clinical deterioration 24-72 hours before acute events. Value-based care models (ACOs, bundled payments, capitation) create direct financial incentive for hospitals and payers to invest in RPM -- every prevented hospitalization saves $15K-30K. The technology stack: connected devices (BP cuffs, glucose monitors, pulse oximeters, smart scales) + AI analytics layer + clinical workflow integration + patient engagement tools. The demographic urgency: 10,000 Americans turning 65 daily through 2030.
model_cards.composite_note: 69.5, adjusted to 69.0 reflecting reimbursement uncertainty and competitive saturation.
model_cards.category_rationale: FA 8 >= 7 = FORCE_RIDER. 4-force convergence (F1+F2+F4+F5). SN 8 reflects real chronic disease management need. EC 5 is the drag -- the RPM market is highly competitive (Livongo/Teladoc, Dexcom, Abbott, Omada, hundreds of startups) with unclear winner-take-all dynamics. CE 6 reflects hardware+software economics and complex integration requirements. TG 7 reflects steady adoption that has been 'imminent' for years but is now genuinely scaling.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: US RPM market >$18B by 2026. 33% adoption rate. 95% of 65+ have chronic conditions. Value-based care models create direct financial incentive. CMS reimbursement codes for RPM established (CPT 99453-99458). Hospital-at-home programs (419 hospitals, 39 states) require RPM infrastructure. Wearable health device market $187.6B by 2026. AI predictive analytics can identify deterioration 24-72 hours before acute events. Each prevented hospitalization saves $15K-30K.
what_must_be_true: CMS RPM reimbursement codes (CPT 99453-99458) remain stable or expand
Patient engagement with connected devices sustained beyond initial 90-day novelty period (historical dropout rate 40-60%)
AI predictive analytics demonstrate clinically significant hospitalization reduction in randomized controlled trials
Value-based care models expand (ACO enrollment, bundled payment adoption) creating payer demand

model_cards.name: Healthcare Compliance & Regulatory AI
model_cards.one_liner: AI platform that continuously monitors and interprets the 1,200+ state AI bills, CMS rule changes, HIPAA updates, and Joint Commission requirements to keep health systems compliant with an increasingly complex and conflicting regulatory patchwork
model_cards.macro_source: Healthcare faces a regulatory explosion: 1,200+ state AI bills introduced in 2025 (on pace to exceed in 2026), CMS rule changes across every payment setting, HIPAA privacy enforcement intensifying, Joint Commission standards evolving, FDA AI device regulations, and now state-level AI chatbot safety laws (Illinois SB 3261, SB 3263). No single compliance team can track, interpret, and implement this volume of regulatory change manually. Healthcare organizations spend 15-20% of operating costs on regulatory compliance. The federal preemption vs state law conflict on AI regulation means health systems operating in multiple states face CONFLICTING requirements. AI compliance monitoring that continuously scans, interprets, and generates implementation guidance is becoming as essential as legal counsel.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 68.0 = CONDITIONAL, borderline FORCE_RIDER (FA 7 = threshold). The regulatory complexity is real but the market for healthcare regulatory AI is nascent and unproven at scale. SN 7 reflects genuine need but not existential urgency (health systems have existing compliance teams). EC 6 reflects moderate competition from general RegTech platforms entering healthcare. TG 7 reflects steady regulatory acceleration. CE 7 reflects SaaS economics with reasonable capital needs.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: 1,200+ state AI bills in 2025. Federal preemption vs state law conflict. CMS site-neutral payment, electronic prior auth mandate (CMS-0057-F), IPO list phase-out, hospital-at-home waiver. FDA AI clinical decision support deregulation. Illinois leading with multiple AI bills. Healthcare compliance costs 15-20% of operating budget. Multi-state health systems face conflicting AI regulations. Dedicated responsible AI roles in banks growing 21% in 6 months (CS09) -- same trend emerging in healthcare.
what_must_be_true: State-level AI regulation continues accelerating (1,200+ bills is the floor, not the ceiling)
Federal preemption does NOT resolve the patchwork (if federal law preempts, the compliance burden simplifies and reduces the market)
Health systems allocate budget for regulatory AI tools rather than expanding human compliance teams
AI regulatory interpretation accuracy is sufficient for legal reliance (lawyers trust the AI output)

model_cards.name: Surgical Robotics AI Enhancement Layer
model_cards.sector_name: Specialty (Except Psychiatric and Substance Abuse) Hospitals
model_cards.one_liner: AI software layer for surgical robotics systems that provides intra-operative guidance, complication prediction, and surgeon performance analytics -- riding the 13-15% annual procedure growth trajectory of a $14B global surgical robotics market
model_cards.macro_source: Surgical robotics market $14B globally in 2026, growing 15% CAGR through 2030. Intuitive Surgical dominates with 60%+ market share and 2.68M procedures in 2024 (+18% YoY in 2025). Da Vinci 5 launched with enhanced sensing and AI capabilities. Procedure growth forecast: 13-15% for 2026. The AI enhancement layer opportunity is DISTINCT from the hardware platform: it sits on top of surgical robotics to provide (1) intra-operative tissue recognition (avoiding critical structures), (2) real-time complication risk prediction, (3) post-operative analytics for surgeon training, (4) procedure standardization across a health system. The analog is how Tesla's AI software creates value on top of EV hardware. Specialty hospitals (6223) growing 6.7% -- fastest in hospital subsector -- driven largely by surgical center expansion.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 63.5 = CONDITIONAL. The opportunity is real (surgical robotics growing rapidly) but the AI software layer faces a structural challenge: Intuitive Surgical builds its own AI capabilities (da Vinci 5) and controls the hardware platform. Third-party AI must either partner with or compete against a $180B market cap incumbent. EC 5 reflects this platform dependence risk. SN 7 reflects genuine surgical safety improvement potential. FA 6 -- only two forces. CE 7 reflects pure software economics but with long regulatory/clinical validation cycles.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: Global surgical robotics $14B (2026). Intuitive 60%+ market share. 2.68M da Vinci procedures in 2024. Procedure growth 13-15% forecast for 2026. Da Vinci 5 with enhanced AI. New competitors: Medtronic Hugo, J&J Ottava entering market. NAICS 6223 growth 6.7%. Specialty hospitals and ASCs driving volume migration from general hospitals.
what_must_be_true: Intuitive Surgical maintains open platform approach allowing third-party AI software (not guaranteed)
AI intra-operative guidance demonstrates measurable complication reduction in peer-reviewed studies
FDA regulatory pathway for intra-operative AI guidance is navigable (novel regulatory territory)
Surgeons adopt AI guidance rather than viewing it as threat to clinical autonomy

model_cards.name: AI Prior Authorization Automation Engine
model_cards.one_liner: AI engine that automates the prior authorization process end-to-end -- from clinical documentation extraction to payer-specific rule matching to appeal generation -- targeting the 14-day average PA delay and 34% claim abandonment rate, with CMS-mandated electronic PA by 2027 as regulatory tailwind
model_cards.macro_source: Prior authorization is the single most hated administrative process in healthcare. Average PA takes 14 days. 34% of denied claims are abandoned (revenue permanently lost). Physicians report spending 13 hours/week on PA activities. CMS-0057-F mandates electronic prior authorization by 2027 for Medicare Advantage and Medicaid -- creating a regulatory forcing function. AMA estimates $31B+ annual cost of PA activities. AI can: (1) extract relevant clinical data from EHR, (2) match against payer-specific PA rules, (3) pre-populate PA forms, (4) predict approval probability, (5) generate appeal documentation for denials. The unique timing: CMS mandate creates a cliff event where ALL payers must accept electronic PA by 2027.
model_cards.composite_note: 73.0, adjusted to 73.5 for CMS mandate urgency.
model_cards.category_rationale: TG 9 >= 8 AND SN 8 >= 6 = TIMING_ARBITRAGE. CE 8 >= 8 AND SN 8 >= 6 = CAPITAL_MOAT. The CMS 2027 mandate creates the clearest timing signal in healthcare AI. Every payer and provider MUST have electronic PA capability by 2027 -- this is not optional adoption, it is regulatory compliance. Capital efficiency is high (SaaS, 3-4mo to revenue, 75%+ margins). EC 5 reflects competition from established PA vendors (CoverMyMeds, Availity) adding AI and from EHR vendors building PA modules.
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: Prior auth: 14-day average delay, 34% claim abandonment. AMA estimates $31B+ annual PA cost. Physicians spend 13 hours/week on PA. CMS-0057-F mandates electronic PA by 2027. AI PA automation can reduce processing time from days to hours. Approval prediction enables targeted clinical documentation improvement. Appeal generation AI recovers abandoned revenue. The CMS mandate is the forcing function -- compliance deadline is binary.
what_must_be_true: CMS-0057-F electronic prior auth mandate enforced on schedule (January 1, 2027)
Payer API endpoints for electronic PA are functional and standardized (interoperability requirement)
AI prior auth accuracy sufficient for health systems to reduce PA staffing (85%+ auto-approval rate)
EHR vendors do not bundle PA automation at zero cost, commoditizing the market

model_cards.name: Behavioral Health AI Platform
model_cards.sector_name: Psychiatric and Substance Abuse Hospitals / Mental Health Services
model_cards.one_liner: AI-powered platform for behavioral health providers combining intelligent intake assessment, treatment matching, real-time symptom monitoring via smartphone sensors, and therapist augmentation tools to address the 160M Americans in mental health professional shortage areas
model_cards.macro_source: 160M Americans live in mental health professional shortage areas. Mental health demand surging post-COVID and sustained (other health practitioners NAICS 6213 growing 6.8% -- fastest in ambulatory, driven by mental health). Average wait time for a psychiatrist: 6-8 weeks. Behavioral health is uniquely positioned for AI augmentation because: (1) the shortage is extreme, (2) much of therapy is conversation-based (where LLMs excel), (3) smartphone sensor data (sleep, activity, social engagement) provides continuous symptom monitoring between sessions, (4) treatment matching (which therapy for which condition) is a classification problem AI can augment. BUT: fear friction is HIGHEST in mental health -- patients trust AI least for emotional/psychological care. The model must augment therapists, not replace them.
model_cards.category_rationale: Composite 65.5 = CONDITIONAL. High SN (8) reflects acute mental health shortage. FA 7 = FORCE_RIDER threshold. But TG 6 reflects the psychological barrier: mental health AI adoption is the slowest in healthcare because trust in AI for emotional care is lowest. CE 6 reflects moderate capital efficiency -- long clinical validation cycles, complex regulatory landscape for mental health AI (state licensing, liability for AI-influenced treatment decisions). EC 5 reflects competition (Talkspace, BetterHelp, Spring Health, Ginger, plus hundreds of AI chatbot startups).
model_cards.deep_dive_evidence: 160M in mental health shortage areas. 6-8 week average psychiatrist wait. NAICS 6213 (other practitioners including mental health) growing 6.8% -- fastest ambulatory subsector. NAICS 6222 (psychiatric hospitals) growing 2.8% at 126K employees. Mental health parity laws expanding coverage. Smartphone-based symptom monitoring validated in clinical trials. AI treatment matching can improve therapy-condition alignment. But: AI chatbot safety concerns (Illinois SB 3261), deepfake/trust erosion impacts mental health AI trust, and clinical liability for AI-influenced psychiatric treatment is unresolved.
what_must_be_true: Therapists adopt AI augmentation tools (treatment matching, session preparation, symptom tracking) rather than viewing them as threats
State mental health licensing boards do not restrict AI-augmented therapy delivery
AI chatbot safety legislation (Illinois SB 3261, similar) does not create prohibitive compliance burden
Patient engagement with AI-based symptom monitoring sustained beyond initial enrollment period

model_card_summary.gap_analysis_vs_v37: v3-7 covered: staffing (001), clinical decision support (002), revenue cycle (003), travel nurse (004), patient flow (005), workforce reskilling (006), PE turnaround (007), rural health (008). v3-8 fills: ambient documentation (009), pharmacy automation (010), hospital-at-home (011), medical coding (012), senior care monitoring (013), dental AI (014), digital pathology (015), remote patient monitoring (016), healthcare compliance (017), surgical robotics AI (018), prior authorization (019), behavioral health (020). Combined 20-card portfolio covers all major healthcare AI transformation vectors.

v37_to_v38_changes: Nursing shortage quantified: 8% national deficit, 20% LPN shortage, 250K RN gap by 2030 (was qualitative in v3-7, now measured)
AI adoption data strengthened: 22% overall healthcare AI adoption (7x increase over 2024), 92% ambient scribe deployment, 71% hospitals with predictive AI
CMS waiver for hospital-at-home extended through 2030 (was uncertain in v3-7)
PE distress deepened: Steward bankruptcy fully resolved (5 hospitals closed, 2,400 workers laid off), 488 hospitals PE-owned
Counter-signals integrated: CS07-CS09 reframed monoculture from pure fragility to sustainable-with-concentration-risk
2025 jobs revised from 584K to 181K -- healthcare monoculture was UNDERSTATED in real-time data
key_uncertainties_remaining: Whether AI productivity gains flow to cost reduction, margin improvement, or worker compensation
Whether PE distress cascades (>20 hospital closures) or resolves gradually
Whether nursing shortage resolves through immigration, training expansion, or technology (or all three)
Whether patient trust in AI improves or the invisible pathway remains the primary adoption mechanism
Whether CMS reimbursement keeps pace with healthcare cost inflation
